transcripts.text: I think the very first call that I really want to take is Dean in North Carolina.  Dean, how are you doing?
Hey, what's going on, Eric?
Doing the show.  How about you, brother?
I'm just calling into the show.
Yeah?  Say hi to Dave.
Hey, what's going on, Dave?  How you doing, man?  Hey, Dean.
Good to hear from you.
So for people who don't know who Dean is, Dean is an apologist who visited Austin recently.

Yeah, last month, one of the things that I just wanted to say or ask the question is I want to thank everybody who was there about a month ago at the ACA for treating me with hospitality and respect, had a lot of good conversations.  And one of the things that I like to try to promote wherever I can is that even though we disagree on some very serious issues, that there is still the possibility to be civil with one another in a culture that is becoming increasingly uncivil.  So I just want to give a shout out to the ACA and everybody there.  And the next time that I visit, I don't know if Matt Dillahunty is there, but I'd like to challenge Matt Dillahunty to a lip-sync battle of a Taylor Swift song.  Yes!
Throwdown.
Absolutely.  So that is actually a bit of a behind-the-scenes thing.  For people who have not been to the studio, it is a tradition.  I don't think I've ever said this on air before.
Oh, boy.
It has been a tradition that before every single episode, we listen to Taylor Swift.
Okay, don't judge, people.  Don't judge.
Well, because it's so poppy and exciting and haters going to hate.
It does get you going, yeah.

And there's actually a video of every guest that's ever been in this seat singing to Taylor Swift with me.  Just for a moment, go back in your head and think about who's been on this show.  It exists.
I love it.

And it's locked down.  But dude, it was awesome having you out, man.  I absolutely agree.  And I think that you can disagree with someone and not write them off completely.  And that's important because you're not going to get to productive dialogue.  And again, I'll start by saying not everyone's obligated to have these conversations.  And so if... And this is true on the Christian side and the atheist side, and I know you know this is true.  Don't be an asshole to somebody who doesn't want to have that conversation.  Right?  Yeah, no doubt.  That said, for those of us who do want to have that conversation, we can say, hey, I disagree with the content of your argument, but that doesn't mean that I am disparaging the content of your character.
Yeah.
And, Dean, you stayed at my house.  You slept on my couch when you were out here.
It's funny how many Christians gave me the, what?  You did what?
Did you get any atheists on you?  I was like, yeah.  Yeah, no, it was great.  Did you get any atheist on you?
No, I have the repellent.
Okay, good.  Yeah, that's important that you spray up before you go into an atheist house.
There you go.
Now, disagreement is cool.  I've disagreed with a lot of people who are wrong.  No, I'm just kidding.
That took me a second.  That took me a second.
I can tell you're going, wait, what?
So, Dean, you actually wanted to bring up an apologetic.  You wanted to bring up an argument.

Yeah, so not that I've studied this argument specifically in any type of depth, but I just wanted y'all's opinion on a fairly not new argument that's been around since Paley, but it was recently brought back into frame by Lydia and Tim McGrew.  It's called Undesigned Coincidences, and that's to kind of explain that.  That's when... you know, when an account of one event omits pieces or a piece of information which are incidentally filled in by another account.  So it's kind of like when the police separate the eyewitnesses and they say, hey, what happened?  And this guy says, well, you know, the fight happened at a coffee shop, you know, down on North Main and it was crowded.  And then the other guy says, well, it happened down on North Main and And right before the fight happened, the guy knocked coffee on the other guy.  So those would be two separate accounts that leave out pieces of information but are incidentally filled in.  And I guess from the premise of the argument that it would show that there was no cooperation in certain areas between the two – But we don't have – I'm sorry, but we don't have that with the Bible, do we?  Have what?

We don't have independent accounts outside of the book that they're in.  On top of that, many of those accounts were written after the fact by people who never even met or were with those people and yet include direct narratives and conversations that people had privately.  And so in filling that in, I would say that you could not say that they were... What was the word?  Undesigned?  Because... You can actually see the growth from book to book.  As time goes on, they added to the story.  And so you have, you know, the character of Jesus, Meek and Mild, you know, who said... Who said, Father, take this cup from me.  And you have this progression to a Jesus who is not only, you know, just kicking butt and taking names, but forgiving the people on either side of them and saying, you know, by the end of this day, you'll be with me in heaven.  Those are all... that knew about each other and built on each other, I think it would be more like fan fiction than it would be an uncorroborated story that happens to meet up.
Okay, so I guess from what you're saying then, you don't find that argument convincing because you don't think that those are early.
Well, actually, the thing is I find the argument itself convincing.  Okay.  I don't think it's applicable here.
Okay, okay, gotcha.
Because of the way the books were written and when they were written.

Yeah, I mean, if you were to get multiple eyewitnesses to a thing, that would absolutely help rule out these personal narratives that we read into everything that we do, and that's wonderful.  But when you're taking that and kind of doing it in a post-hoc fashion from a single source, and that source is the... you know, the compiled books of the Bible, then you have all of these really wonky things going on.  Like, if you had... Did you watch Talk Heathen, right, Dean?  Yeah.  Do you remember the guy that called in about prophecy?
Yeah, which guy?

About a week ago, called about fulfilled prophecies.  And it's just difficult for me because... you have, they had the prophecy in, like, if you have the opportunity to make it true, or you have the ability to write that it happened, but be unchallenged on it, then the best we can do is look at that and be like, yeah, that's a thing that was written, but we don't have substantial evidence.

Well, you know, just my personal approach, my cup of tea, is if I'm going to personally argue for the reliability or the historical reliability of something like the resurrection or the historical reliability of the gospels, I'm not going to appeal to fulfilled prophecy because I know more likely than not, and I'm not saying this with
any malice

or disrespect.  I'm not going to say it with any malice or anything like that, but I understand that, you know, and we've had this conversation before, Eric.  I know that you're not going to, that's not going to fly with you, so why am I going to use fulfilled prophecy isn't apologetic when I know that you don't believe that.  So the better thing to do is to just look at these as ancient documents and say, okay, well, are they, you know, historically reliable and not appeal to things like inerrancy or fulfilled prophecy or something like personal experience or somebody else's experience.  So I, in that sense, to a very nuanced level, I agree that I couldn't, there's no way that I could convince you or anybody else probably over there that, you know, the Gospels are historically reliable by talking about fulfilled prophecies.

Well, the problem I have with all of what we're talking about here to begin with is that we're using the Bible to understand the Bible and to make sense of the Bible.  The problem with even the gospel is just going with that because that's the bulk of what we're discussing here.  There's no extra biblical historical writing about Jesus and his activities.  In fact, history proves that some of the things that the Bible says, like there was a census when Jesus was born, that didn't happen.  Mm-hmm.  His history has shown that.  So we've got problems right out of the gate with the veracity of Scripture.  And then when we try to use Scripture to verify Scripture on top of that, and then we're looking to compare coincidences and inconsistencies, the whole thing... is problematic because there's no one in that era that's verifying that these things happen.  I mean, if you've got a zombie apocalypse going on and you've got 500 people wandering around Jerusalem at the resurrection, I would think someone would notice that.
Well, but not everybody takes a literal viewpoint.  Dean, do you think that literally people rose from the dead when Jesus died?

Well, you know, I really don't know, but... Number one, I think that there's a huge debate, even within the apologetics world, about whether or not Matthew means that to be apocalyptic literature of something taking place later down the line, or whether he means that to be literal.  And you'll have guys on both sides that will say it happened, and you'll have guys like Craig and Lacona who will say that it's apocalyptic literature, it's a...
uh, device, it's a, um, literal device used, you know, in, uh, to be a fly on the wall for that conversation, dude.  Yeah.  That is, I live for that.
Yeah.

Um, but, but I would like to just raise a, a minor objection to what David said is, you know, I, I, this, and this is the same, I don't know if it's the exact same issue that I had with, with Noah when he was on, but, um, I guess I don't understand the whole.  use the Bible to prove the Bible.  I mean, that would be like saying if I wanted to know something about Caesar and I had a Roman author, even if he was anonymous, and even if it was written 80 years after the fact and wrote about Caesar, that would be like saying, well, you can't use this document about Caesar to to prove what caesar did because it has caesar action in it.  so i don't understand.  it seems to be a little bit
not quite

to me because because it seems like that's how history is done history is done by taking sources that talk about a certain event or a certain person without appealing to inspiration without appealing to fulfilled prophecy and saying all right What can we gather from these sources about what took place?
Well, to answer that, can I?
Yeah, please.

I just, I mean, at the end of the day, I don't care whether Caesar lived or died or not, because Caesar's not making any claim on my life for heaven or hell.  So I don't give a flying fuck whether Caesar ever lived.  I mean, let's just be real.  But when we're talking about Jesus, the Son of God, and God's blueprint for man, the most important thing ever written according to what Christians would claim, your claim is that God has a claim on my life and that if I don't believe in him, if I don't believe in Jesus, then my eternal destiny hangs in the balance.  That's some pretty important stuff.  No, I agree.  The problem I have with... I would think you would.  The problem I have with the Bible and with the way that God communicated... If I'm God and I want to communicate with all the people of the world all throughout history the most important message in the history of mankind, I'm going to be pretty damn clear about my communications.  And just your example of whether Matthew meant that literally or it was an allegory or it was prophetic or whatever... Why is it so damn complicated?  Why does it take years, eons of people arguing about what the Bible means, what it doesn't mean?  If I'm God and I'm communicating the most important message in the history of mankind, and I'm that muddy with it, I've done a pretty poor job of communicating.  And then tack on that... I'm sorry, go ahead.  And well intact on the lack of any outside sources talking about this person, Jesus, who was supposedly the man who was changing the world.  It's pretty shoddy to me.  It's a shaky foundation at best.

But I think we've got a couple of issues there.  I think one is, you know, trying to surmise the... the reason or purpose behind why God would do something is different than looking at a document and saying whether or not it's history, I think, number one.  But because the Muslims have a claim on your life, too.  Islam has a claim on your life.  But I don't know.  Would you say that we couldn't look at the Quran and see whether or not some of the things that have taken place in the Quran as they're written down, where historical events are not.  I don't know.

I don't know the Quran.  So, I'm just saying.  If you write some things, if you write some things that are going to happen, then you're going to hit them on a certain percentage of them.  You know, like everybody talking about the second coming of Christ, there's going to be wars and rivers, wars and earthquakes and all that.  And they've been saying that since I was a Christian in the 70s.  Well, that shit's been happening for 40 years and he's still not here, I don't think.  Um, he may have come and gone.  I missed him.  I don't know.

If I, yeah, but if I can, I'm just, what I'm just saying is, you know, asking the question about why God would communicate this is different than looking at a document and saying whether it's history or not.  And I think that we can look at documents, whether they're religious in nature or not, and ask the question, all right, is this event like Jesus's crucifixion that's in all four gospels even talked about?  And I don't know whether you're a mysticist or not, but it would seem like it's talked about outside in secular sources.
I'm not sure I agree with that.  I'm not sure I agree with what's talked about in outside sources.  I mean, Josephus mentions Jesus in passing in one thing.  No.  Is that wrong?
So he mentions somebody named Yeshua?
Yeah, exactly.  And that's my point.  That's the only reference that I know of extra biblical.
Well, it might be a reference, but the thing is it's not.
It may not even be, right.
Yeah.

Well, Josephus talks about James, who's the elder at the Jerusalem church, about how He was killed, and he was the brother of Jesus.  Tacitus talks about it as well.  I mean, John Dominic Crofton, who's a member of the Jesus Seminar, who thinks the whole Bible is a metaphor.  says that Jesus' crucifixion is as historical as anything can ever be.
Yeah, but, I mean, I think you would agree...
A guy named Jesus, yeah.
Well, a guy named Jesus, yeah, but if you want to say, you know, supernatural events, we're going to...
Yeah, that's where we break down.

Absolutely, because I think that there's far more evidence of the Bat Cruise yesterday than there was of, you know, a lot of those things, and... I don't want to retread too much.  Right.  But what I will say on the accuracy of the Bible is we're looking at the Bible as a source, a source.  And we need to look at whether or not it's reliable.  And we can point out places where it's not reliable.  And because of that, it does not appear to be a reliable source for information.  So if we're still appealing to it, then we're on shaky ground to begin with.
Yeah, that was what I was trying to say.  You said it better because you're a pro.
No, I mean, actually what I got from what you said is that, you know, if God had the power to be a better communicator, then God would communicate better.

Yeah, that's the thing I've always come back to.  I mean, this is the most important message in the history of mankind.  And the delivery system was pretty bad.  In fact, I'm thinking, why didn't he wait another couple thousand years for... when literacy and the internet and everything, we could have had video footage of the crucifixion and the resurrection.  I mean, you know, Mary and them could have been with an iPhone at the resurrection and just got the whole thing.  Well, let me... Go ahead.
Sorry.
That's all right.  I'm just messing with you.
No, I got you.  So let me ask you this.  If there was the internet and a video, and there was a video of the resurrection, would you believe it?
Um, that's a good question.  I'd be more inclined to give credence to it than I do now, so I'd want to know more about what's going on.
I mean, yeah, evidence needs to be investigated.
Yeah, I mean, strong claims need strong evidence.
With that said, Dean?
I'm sorry, do we have to go?
I could talk to you for days.
So he's going to call you tonight, and you guys can...
Oh, no, he and I actually have a video shot together, and we are going to be continuing to go over philosophy discussions.  Not on this channel, though.

But I had fun out there in Austin.  You know, next time I'm in Austin, I'll stop by the ACA.  I appreciate you guys and the way that you've treated me out there, and... You know, take care, guys.  You're a good dude, Dean.  Hey, I appreciate it, man.  You are, too.
Good conversation, buddy.
Oh, and hey, Dean.  Dean.  Yeah.  We still need to have that talk about the Kalam cosmological argument.
We do, because I have no problem with disagreeing with people who are wrong.
There you go.
Oh, that is such a good callback.
At least you're listening, Dean.  At least you learned something today.  Hey, Dean, carpe the fucking diem.
Take care, brother.
Take care, guys.
